Name: Byzantine Coin of Justinian the First
Description: The Byzantine bronze coin depicts Emperor Justinian the First who reigned from AD 527 to AD 565. The coin was made in the mint of Alexandria. The denomination of the coin is 12 nummia. On the front of the coin is a bust of Justinian the First looking right. He is wearing a diadem, a military cloak and a breastplate that covers his torso. The back side of the coin portrays a cross between the letters "IB". The Greek letters "IB" represent the denomination of the coin. The "I" stands for 10 and the "B" stands for 2 for a total of 12 nummia. It was thought that the long-lasting series of Alexandrian bronze coins of the 12 nummia, or the dodecanummia, denomination was initiated by Justinian the First. Along with the bust of Justinian, the front side of the coin has a Latin legend starting with DN, the abbreviation of "Dominus Noster," or Our Lord. The legend continues with the name of the emperor and ends with his titles "PPAVG," or Perpetuus Augustus, or a similar phrase. Beneath the exergual line is the name of the mint in Greek. The exergual line separates the portion of the coin that is beneath the main design. Only the first four letters of the name of the mint are present.
